336d898217ee.shortDescription: Our community publishes stories worth reading on…

paragraphs.text: Unlike data scientists — and inspired by our more mature parent, software engineering — data engineers build tools, infrastructure, frameworks, and services. In fact, it’s arguable that data engineering is much closer to software engineering than it is to a data science.

paragraphs.name: 2ae2
paragraphs.text: ETL is changing

The data engineering team will often own pockets of certified, high quality areas in the data warehouse. At Airbnb for instance, there’s a set of “core” schemas that are managed by the data engineering team, where service level agreement (SLAs) are clearly defined and measured, naming conventions are strictly followed, business metadata and documentation is of the highest quality, and the related pipeline code follows a set of well defined best practices.

paragraphs.name: 43d3
paragraphs.text: In larger environments, there tends to be specialization and the creation of a formal role to manage this workload, as the need for a data infrastructure team grows. In those organizations, the role of automating some of the data engineering processes falls under the hand of both the data engineering and data infrastructure teams, and it’s common for these teams to collaborate to solve higher level problems.

paragraphs.name: d595
paragraphs.text: This is a fantastic article, thanks Maxime Beauchemin. My company did some research on data engineers based off of their self identified skills and experience as well as job posting data from around the web. There are only 6,500 people who call themselves data engineers in the world, but there are over 6,600 job openings for data engineers in San…

paragraphs.name: 8fa8
paragraphs.text: Good insight — thanks for sharing! Now I’m wondering if it’s time to revitalize concepts like the Software Factories (http://resources.sei.cmu.edu/library/asset-view.cfm?assetID=31189) and Domain Specific Languages (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb126278.aspx) and transform them into the context of Data.

paragraphs.text: Note that I’m not arguing that people don’t need abstractions, GUIs, or that everyone should write data pipelines as code, but I’m arguing that it’s the job of data engineers to create the actual abstractions that their peers need, the inputs (GUI / config file / code) and outputs (dashboards, tabular datasets, csvs) of these “data engineering…

1ff95e77eac1.title: Great posts on the emerging role of “Data Engineers”.

paragraphs.name: 6db7
paragraphs.text: Great posts on the emerging role of “Data Engineers”. For mainstream enterprises, I see the Ops folks morphing into “Data Engineers” though they may not have all the “Developer” skills. The onus is for the ecosystem to provide “tools” to make these Ops folks successfully transition into the Data Engineer roles. You need to get this right to fully realize the value of these data platforms.

paragraphs.text: My first job on wall street was “process automation” for backoffice processes which was basically writing a bunch of “ETL” bash scripts and automating them via CA’s Autosys platform that was essentially a CRON with more features.

paragraphs.text: Maybe I’m late in realizing this but Airflow looks like an open-source version of CA’s Autosys!
